title: Reciprocal Sum
content: The reciprocal sum of a set A is Σ_{n∈A} 1/n. We use rationals (ℚ) to ensure exact arithmetic. This measures the 'weight' of a set in terms of its unit fractions.

title: Unit Set
content: A set is a 'unit set' if all its elements are positive and their reciprocals sum to exactly 1. These are Egyptian fraction representations of 1, like {2,3,6} since 1/2+1/3+1/6=1.

title: Classic Example
content: The set {2,3,6} is a unit set: 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/6 = 3/6 + 2/6 + 1/6 = 6/6 = 1. This is the smallest such set and the most familiar Egyptian fraction for 1.

title: Pairwise Disjoint
content: A collection of sets is pairwise disjoint if no integer belongs to more than one set. This constraint makes packing multiple unit sets challenging: once an integer is used, it's unavailable.

title: Unit Set Packing
content: A valid packing consists of multiple disjoint unit sets, all contained in {1,...,N}. The structure tracks: the list of sets, that each is a unit set, that all elements are ≤N, and that sets are disjoint.

title: The Function k(N)
content: k(N) is the maximum number of disjoint unit sets that can be packed into {1,...,N}. This is the central quantity Erdős asked about: how does it grow with N?

title: k(N) ≥ 1
content: For N ≥ 6, we can fit at least one unit set: {2,3,6}. This is the trivial lower bound establishing k(N) is non-zero for reasonable N.

title: Trivial Upper Bound
content: k(N) ≤ N since disjoint sets can't collectively contain more than N elements. This is a weak bound but shows k(N) is finite.

title: Sunflower Lower Bound
content: Using the sunflower lemma, one can construct at least N·exp(-O(√log N)) disjoint sets with equal reciprocal sums (though not necessarily equal to 1). This gives a sublinear but superpolylogarithmic bound.

title: Hunter-Sawhney Lower Bound
content: For any ε > 0 and large N: k(N) ≥ (1-ε)·log N. Combined with the upper bound, this shows k(N) = (1-o(1))·log N. The proof uses Bloom's Theorem 3 on unit fraction density.

title: Logarithmic Upper Bound
content: k(N) ≤ log N + O(1). This follows because each unit set must use at least one integer ≤ some threshold, and there aren't enough small integers to support more than ~log N disjoint sets.

title: Main Asymptotic Result
content: k(N)/log N → 1 as N → ∞. This is the definitive answer: k(N) grows exactly like log N, neither faster nor slower asymptotically.

title: Not Sublogarithmic
content: k(N) is NOT o(log N), directly answering Erdős's question. The proof is by contradiction: if k(N)/log N → 0, it would contradict k(N)/log N → 1.

title: Infinitely Often Large
content: For any 0 < ε < 1, there are infinitely many N with k(N) > ε·log N. This constructive corollary shows k(N) genuinely achieves near-logarithmic values, not just in the limit.
